I don't recall where I originally saw it (it was a book on abortions statistics), but here is a similar  one I found online:
 
 

 Of course another poof that the number of abortions performed were the same pre and post Roe can be provided by looking at the birth records. If legalizing abortion suddenly increased the number of abortions the birth rate should have shown a balancing drop as pregnancies were now being terminated instead of being carried to term. But the records show it stayed the same. There was no sudden drop and in fact ligalizinf abortion had little effect at all on the birth rate. In fact as the recorded number of abortions was increasing the birth rate was also increasing.
 
 Year Births Birthrate
 
 1973 3,136,965 14.9
 1974 3,159,958 14.9
 1975 3,144,198 14.8
 1976 3,167,788 14.8
 1977 3,326,632 15.4
 1978 3,333,279 15.3
 1979 3,494,398 15.9
 1980 3,612,258 15.9 
 
 Ectopic pregnancies didn't spike after 1973, as they would have if hundreds of thousands more women were having pregnancies they would otherwise have prevented if abortion had stayed a crime in most states, and births/birth rates didn't drop precipitously either, as they would have if women were aborting hundreds of thousands of pregnancies they would otherwise have carried to term. So the only conclusion left is that legal abortions were replacing illegal ones

 I remember one woman who was in her 7th month of pregnancy, and she was taken to the emergency room of the hospital where I worked. All of a sudden she went into V-Fib ( Ventricular fibrillation ), which causes an arrhythmia (erratic head beat, more commonly known as cardic arrest. She was quickly transferred to the trauma centre, where I worked to take the baby thru Caersarian Section. I worked with 4 other M.D.'s trying to save both lives, and our work was valiant, to say the least. Sadly, we lost both the mother, and the child, no matter the heroics we used. I go to bed many a night, and I still see that lady's picture, and the stress she was in.

 So what do you believe "murder" to be then?
 
 You see for me murder, or 1st degree homicide if you prefer, is a term that describes the unlawful premediated killing of a person (a definition I can back up) by another. There are clear instances where it is applicable, and clear instances where it is not (manslaughter, death by dangerous driving and so on). Don't forget that in this context a person is also a legal entity with defined meaning.
 
 For you murder is a term that you apply to ending of a life/existance in a context that offends you- there is no actual "meaning" to justify your use of the word. By your example, we could postulate that any killing can be described as murder because you have no context to frame your use of the term. You might counter and say lawful killing is not murder (ie. Soldier killing an enemy in time of war), but anyone can rubbish that position by asserting that by their feelings they think that instance is murder just because they personally believe it is wrong.
 
 So you basically use the term based on your passions and not any reason- see the arbitary and potentailly shifting nature of such an approach, especially when applied to a group of people at large?
 
 You seem to think you talk in such bold absolutes when you talk of abortion as being murder, but I see the opposite. Aside from my own opinions on the subject of abortion, I find this part of your attitude highly objectionable in itself.
 
 Oh, and the law is the determination between what is right and wrong, throw that notion out the window and you have an vigilante society.

Amendment IV
 
 The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.

The infant has the same rights and value as any other human being, but is unfortunately in the wrong place at the wrong time.

You were still allowed to do whatever you wanted with your own body...but someone came along and shot you in the head. However, without personal autonomy a right to life can still exist. An EXTREME example would be a child. The child is forced to do as the mother/father says and is forced to go to school and forced to do many things with his/her own body however the child can't be killed illegally.

It does if you wish to prove the right exists beyond government. Otherwise if the government got rid of the "rigth" then you could have no objection what so ever to it because they aren't denying you a right because it doesn't exist. In fact, we would never "create" new rights (think back to the days of slavery) because one could not claim a right that doesn't exist.
 I thought that it was obvious that rights are prior to government and are assumed by a body politic, the society and culture that creates the space in which a government apparatus may be erected. 
 
So if you say the right still exists beyond government then you would need to show where it came from.
 And I keep pointing out that this right is a necessary component of any rights-based system such that anyone who agrees that there are rights must agree that there is a right to personal autonomy.

Why? The US has no right to personal autonomy. I see no law that says this. Search and Seizure doesn't work as that is not personal autonomy. That is having the right for someone ELSE to not search you. Nothing about you being able to do what you want to do to yourself.
 As I read the passage:
Amendment IV
 
 The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.
 So you wouldn't call being required to host an unwanted fetus as an unreasonable seizure of their person? Security of persons against unreasonable search and seizure seems to me to constitute the very essence of a right to personal autonomy - the gov't doesn't get to dispose of your body or possessions without your permission. It can't sell you into slavery, for example. 
 
Yeah read it. IT makes no sense as a right to life is essential for any other right.
 You may want to re-read it because I explain how a right to life is incidental or derivative of more essential rights, and how it is necessarily trumped by these rights, including the right to personal autonomy.
 
 Here's the gist, so you know what to read for: 
 A right to personal autonomy is necessary as a structural component of a system of rights, because it defines how ownership is resolved in a system of rights. The possession and exercise of these rights are incidental to the possession of life. Any right to life is therefore either derivative of these foundational rights, or participates in an incoherent system of rights. Either way, a right to life is trumped by a right to personal autonomy.
 
 Then don't respond...and I did read it by the way.
 I'm sorry, it's just that you don't seem to be responding as though you read and understood the material.
Symbiote

a right to life is essential for any other right.

 
 Actually, a right to life makes all other rights meaningless and is in itself contradictory.
 
 If there is enough food for one, and two people have a "right to life", both people have a right to the food. But rights are about the allocation of scarce resources, and a system of rights which ignores this generates irreconcilable conflicts, it can be no basis for social interaction.
 
 For a more practical example, we could extend many peoples' lives by providing them with the very best medical treatment and doctors. But they cannot all be provided with such treatment. The right to life cannot be consistently maintained, and as such cannot be considered a "right", but a vague principle to be applied where the applicant fancies - the conservative applies it to babies, the socialist to the poor, the environmentalist to the quality of the environment, the pharmaceutical giants to the supply of drugs.
 
 
The US has no right to personal autonomy.

 
 Funnily enough, this is what is known as the right to life, as in "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness". True, it is not specifically enshrined in the constitution (nevertheless, the specific absence of it shall not be used to disparage its existence), but it is clearly enumerated in the declaration of independence.

 Well, that is the issue here- you say that abortion is wrong and murder (I guess you mean an abortion by choice as opposed to medical need, but maybe you think any abortion is murder) but where does that view come from? I mean, it is far less qualified than the complex balance of opinion that decides national law on abortion that draws on expertise from all parties in the debate.
 
 But despite this arbitary position (you choose to ignore the reasons of the for allowing abortion, unlike the law which has considered them) you expect to be taken seriously- that will never happen as long as you continue to do the intellectual equivalent of giving so many important issues the finger. How can any such approach become a "standard of right and wrong" when you are deaf to the reality of the issue as a whole?
 
 
However, if you have no government does that mean it is ok for someone to steal from you? You would be ok with this as you would find nothing wrong with it because no law says it is wrong.

 
 I think theft is wrong, government or no government. I also think a woman should have some control over the fact that nature has given her all the responsibility in growing a baby, government or no government.

 The law is how we articulate notions such as theft being wrong into meaning in society- theft is not right, but it is the law that gives that definition and meaning through the punishment the state bestows on those found guilty of that crime.
 
 The same is true without law- people are still going to be ticked off if someone steals from them, but what you do about that has no boundaries except that which the individual chooses to observe.
